data.short_description: The Eight Limbs of Yoga, also known as Ashtanga Yoga, is a system developed by the ancient sage Patanjali to guide practitioners towards spiritual growth and liberation. These eight limbs form a comprehensive framework that includes ethical guidelines, physical practices, breathing techniques, meditation, and self-realization. By practicing the eight limbs of yoga, practitioners can cultivate a balanced, peaceful, and fulfilling life, both on and off the mat. Below is a brief description of each of the eight limbs of yoga:

data: Isvara pranidhana: surrender to higher power
Physical postures designed to promote strength, flexibility, and balance in the body.
Breathing techniques to increase the flow of prana (life force energy) in the body and calm the mind.
Withdrawal of the senses from external distractions and turning inward towards the self.
Concentration and focused attention on a single point, such as the breath or a mantra.
Meditation, the continuous flow of focused attention on the object of meditation.
State of complete absorption in the object of meditation, leading to ultimate self-realization and liberation.
